sen.j: ところてん（心太または心天、瓊脂）は、テングサやオゴノリなどの海藻類をゆでて煮溶かし、発生した寒天質を冷まして固めた食品。
sen.e: Tokoroten, written in Japanese as ところてん, 心太, 心天, or 瓊脂, is food made by boiling seaweed such as tengusa (Gelidiaceae) and ogonori (Chinese moss) until they melt and produce agar, which is then cooled down until set.

Tokoroten, written in Japanese as ところてん, 心太, 心天, or 瓊脂, is food made by boiling seaweed such as tengusa (Gelidiaceae) and ogonori (Chinese moss) until they melt and produce agar, which is then cooled down until set.

Tokoroten, written in Japanese as ところてん, 心太, 心天, or 瓊脂, is food made by boiling seaweed such as tengusa (Gelidiaceae) and ogonori (Chinese moss) until they melt and produce agar, which is then cooled down until set.

sen.j: それを「天突き」とよばれる専用の器具を用いて、押し出しながら細い糸状（麺状）に切った形態が一般的である。
sen.e: Commonly, the agar is then placed in a device called "tentsuki" which squeezes out and cuts the agar into thin, threadlike shapes (like noodles).
Commonly, the agar is then placed in a device called "tentsuki" which squeezes out and cuts the agar into thin, threadlike shapes (like noodles).
Commonly, the agar is then placed in a device called "tentsuki" which squeezes out and cuts the agar into thin, threadlike shapes (like noodles).

sen.j: 全体の98-99％が水分で、残りの成分のほとんどは多糖類（ガラクタン）である。
sen.e: Ninety-eight to ninety-nine percent of the entirety consists of water, and the remaining ingredients are mostly polysaccharide (galactan).
Ninety-eight to ninety-nine percent of the entirety consists of water, and the remaining ingredients are mostly polysaccharide (galactan).
Ninety-eight to ninety-nine percent of the entirety consists of water, and the remaining ingredients are mostly polysaccharide (galactan).

sen.j: 高分子ゲル状の物体であるが、ゼリーなどとは異なり表面はやや堅く感じられ、独特の食感がある。
sen.e: While tokoroten is a substance in a form of macromolecular gel, it differs from other food such as jelly in that it has a unique texture of the surface feeling somewhat hard when eaten.
While tokoroten is a substance in a form of macromolecular gel, it differs from other food such as jelly in that it has a unique texture of the surface feeling somewhat hard when eaten.
While tokoroten is a substance in a form of macromolecular gel, it differs from other food such as jelly in that it has a unique texture of the surface feeling somewhat hard when eaten.

sen.j: 腸内で消化されないため栄養価はほとんどないが、食物繊維として整腸効果がある。
sen.e: There is hardly any nutritional value since it is not digested in the intestines, but being dietary fiber, it has the effect of regulating the functions of intestines.
There is hardly any nutritional value since it is not digested in the intestines, but being dietary fiber, it has the effect of regulating the functions of intestines.
There is hardly any nutritional value since it is not digested in the intestines, but being dietary fiber, it has the effect of regulating the functions of intestines.

sen.j: 関東地方以北および中国地方以西では三杯酢あるいは三杯酢をかけた物にからしを添えて、近畿地方では黒砂糖をかけて単体又は果物などと共に、東海地方では箸一本で、主に三杯酢をかけた物にゴマを添えて食べるのが一般的とされる。
sen.e: Commonly in the north of Kanto region and in the west of Chugoku region, tokoroten is served by sanbaizu (vinegar, soy sauce and mirin (or sugar) mixed in roughly equal proportions) poured over it, or by sanbaizu poured over it and with mustard; in the Kinki region, muscovado sugar is sprinkled over it when served, and sometimes fruit is served together; in the Tokai region, it is eaten using only one chopstick, usually by pouring sanbaizu over it and adding sesame thereto.

Commonly in the north of Kanto region and in the west of Chugoku region, tokoroten is served with sanbaizu (vinegar, soy sauce and mirin (or sugar) mixed in roughly equal proportions) poured over it, or with sanbaizu poured over it and with mustard; in the Kinki region, muscovado sugar is sprinkled over it when served, and sometimes fruit is served together; in the Tokai region, it is eaten using only one chopstick, usually by pouring sanbaizu over it and adding sesame thereto.
sen.cmt: served by をserved withに変更（二か所）
sen.e: Commonly in the north of Kanto region and in the west of Chugoku region, tokoroten is served with sanbaizu (vinegar, soy sauce and mirin (or sugar) mixed in roughly equal proportions) poured over it, or with sanbaizu poured over it and with mustard; in the Kinki region, muscovado sugar is sprinkled over it when served, and sometimes fruit is served together; in the Tokai region, it is eaten using only one chopstick, usually by pouring sanbaizu over it and adding sesame thereto.

sen.j: また、醤油系のタレなどで食べる地方もある。
sen.e: In some areas, it is also served with a sauce which is flavored with soy sauce.
In some areas, it is also served with a sauce which is flavored with soy sauce.
In some areas, it is also served with a sauce which is flavored with soy sauce.

sen.j: テングサを天日に干し、洗浄する。
sen.e: Tengusa is dried in the sun and cleansed.
Tengusa is dried in the sun and cleansed.
Tengusa is dried in the sun and cleansed.

sen.j: これをテングサの色が白くなるまで数回繰り返す。
sen.e: This is repeated several times until the tengusa turns white.
This is repeated several times until the tengusa turns white.
This is repeated several times until the tengusa turns white.

sen.j: この後1年程度冷暗所で保管する。
sen.e: The tengusa is then stored in a cool dark place for about one year.
The tengusa is then stored in a cool dark place for about one year.
The tengusa is then stored in a cool dark place for about one year.

sen.j: 大きめの鍋に上記のテングサを入れ、水をテングサがつかる程度まで入れ、沸騰させる。
sen.e: The above tengusa is placed in a large pan with enough water to soak the tengusa, and the water is boiled.
The above tengusa is placed in a large pan with enough water to soak the tengusa, and the water is boiled.
The above tengusa is placed in a large pan with enough water to soak the tengusa, and the water is boiled.

sen.j: 沸騰後は弱火にて1時間程度煮る。
sen.e: Once the water boils, the tengusa is cooked on low heat for about one hour.
Once the water boils, the tengusa is cooked on low heat for about one hour.
Once the water boils, the tengusa is cooked on low heat for about one hour.

sen.j: 布などで濾して、不純物を取り除き、バットなどの容器に移し替える。
sen.e: The tengusa is strained through cloth and the like to remove impurities, and is moved into a container such as a tray.
The tengusa is strained through cloth and the like to remove impurities, and is moved into a container such as a tray.
The tengusa is strained through cloth and the like to remove impurities, and is moved into a container such as a tray.

sen.j: 容器に移し替えた後、3時間程度、自然に放熱させ、固める（冷蔵庫では失敗しやすい）。
sen.e: Once moved into a container, the tengusa is then left for about three hours to lose heat naturally, until set (this tends to fail when the tengusa is cooled in a refrigerator).
Once moved into a container, the tengusa is then left for about three hours to lose heat naturally, until set (it tends to fail that the tengusa is cooled in a refrigerator).
sen.cmt: 括弧内の説明文の構成見直し
sen.e: Once moved into a container, the tengusa is then left for about three hours to lose heat naturally, until set (it tends to fail that the tengusa is cooled in a refrigerator).

sen.j: 天突きで突いて（無ければ包丁などで細長く切って）完成。
sen.e: Tentsuki is used to squeeze out the tokoroten (if there is no tentsuki, a knife and the like may be used instead to cut the tokoroten into long threads), and tokoroten is ready to be served.
Tentsuki is used to squeeze out the tokoroten (if there is no tentsuki, a knife and the like may be used instead to cut the tokoroten into long threads), and tokoroten is ready to be served.
Tentsuki is used to squeeze out the tokoroten (if there is no tentsuki, a knife and the like may be used instead to cut the tokoroten into long threads), and tokoroten is ready to be served.

sen.j: ところてんを戸外で凍結乾燥させたものが寒天である。
sen.e: Kanten is made by freeze-drying the tokoroten outdoors.
Kanten is made by freeze-drying the tokoroten outdoors.
Kanten is made by freeze-drying the tokoroten outdoors.

sen.j: 一説には、こころぶとと呼ばれ、心太の漢字があてられた。
sen.e: According to one theory, tokoroten was called "kokorobuto" and given the Chinese character 心太 accordingly.
According to one theory, tokoroten was called "kokorobuto" and given the Chinese character 心太 accordingly.
According to one theory, tokoroten was called "kokorobuto" and given the Chinese character 心太 accordingly.

sen.j: それがこころていと呼ばれるようになり、さらに転じてところてんとなったとされるが、古くは正倉院の書物中に心天と記されている事から奈良時代には既にこころてんまたはところてんと呼ばれていた様である。
sen.e: Then it came to be called "kokorotei", and by further extension, "tokoroten"; however, it seems that names such as "kokoroten" and "tokoroten" were already used in the Nara period as is shown by its mention in days gone by in a writing stored in Shoso-in Treasure Repository.

Then it came to be called "kokorotei", and by further extension, "tokoroten"; however, it seems that names such as "kokoroten" and "tokoroten" were already used in the Nara period as is shown by its mention in days gone by in a writing stored in Shoso-in Treasure Repository.

Then it came to be called "kokorotei", and by further extension, "tokoroten"; however, it seems that names such as "kokoroten" and "tokoroten" were already used in the Nara period as is shown by its mention in days gone by in a writing stored in Shoso-in Treasure Repository.

tit.j: 儀式としてのところてん
tit.cmt: ritual をRitualとした（表題なので）。

sen.j: 奈良時代、正倉院の木簡に記されている記録では御食国と呼ばれる地域からテングサを宮中に送った記録がある。
sen.e: A record in a mokukan (narrow, long, and thin pieces of wood strung together that were used to write on in ancient times) stored in Shoso-in Treasure Repository shows that in the Nara period, tengusa was sent to the Imperial Court from areas called Miketsukuni (literally, "land of royal provisions").

A record in a mokukan (narrow, long, and thin pieces of wood strung together that were used to write on in ancient times) stored in Shoso-in Treasure Repository shows that in the Nara period, tengusa was sent to the Imperial Court from areas called Miketsukuni (literally, "land of royal provisions").

A record in a mokukan (narrow, long, and thin pieces of wood strung together that were used to write on in ancient times) stored in Shoso-in Treasure Repository shows that in the Nara period, tengusa was sent to the Imperial Court from areas called Miketsukuni (literally, "land of royal provisions").

sen.j: 節料として収められ、当時宮中における節気行事などに使用されていたことが伺える。
sen.e: This record reflects that tengusa was kept as sechiryo (food and drink of events or its expense) and used in sekki gyoji (events of 24 divisions of the solar year) and other events at the Imperial Court of the time.

This record reflects that tengusa was kept as sechiryo (food and drink of events or its expense) and used in sekki gyoji (events of 24 divisions of the solar year) and other events at the Imperial Court of the time.

This record reflects that tengusa was kept as sechiryo (food and drink of events or its expense) and used in sekki gyoji (events of 24 divisions of the solar year) and other events at the Imperial Court of the time.

sen.j: 俳句においては夏の季語のひとつである。
sen.e: "Tokoroten" is one of the kigo (season words) for summer in haiku.
"Tokoroten" is one of the kigo (season words) for summer in haiku.
"Tokoroten" is one of the kigo (season words) for summer in haiku.

tit.j: 軒下の拵へ滝や心太 小林一茶
tit.e: Nokishita no koshirae taki ya tokoroten (by Issa KOBAYASHI) Here, under the eaves, tokoroten looks like a waterfall.
Nokishita no koshirae taki ya tokoroten (by Issa KOBAYASHI) Here, under the eaves, tokoroten looks like a waterfall.
Here, under the eaves, tokoroten looks like a waterfall (by Issa KOBAYASHI).

sen.j: 清滝の水汲ませてやところてん 松尾芭蕉
sen.e: Kiyotaki no mizu kumasete ya tokoroten (by Basho MATSUO) This tokoroten is full of coolness. It must have been made with the water by carried from the Kiyotaki-gawa River.
Kiyotaki no mizu kumasete ya tokoroten (by Basho MATSUO) This tokoroten is full of coolness. It must have been made with the water by carried from the Kiyotaki-gawa River.
This tokoroten is full of coolness, which must have been made with the water by carried from the Kiyotaki-gawa River (by Basho MATSUO).

tit.j: ところてんに関連する派生語・作品等
tit.e: Derivative words and works, etc. related to tokoroten
Derivative Words and Works, etc. related to Tokoroten
tit.cmt: 出現単語の先頭を大文字化
tit.e: Derivative Words and Works, etc. related to Tokoroten

sen.j: 派生語
sen.e: Derivative words
Derivative words
Derivative words

sen.j: ところてん式（昇進）
sen.e: Tokoroten-shiki (promotion)
Tokoroten-shiki (promotion)
Tokoroten-shiki (promotion)

sen.j: ところてんのように、押し出されて自然と前へ進んでいく様子のこと。
sen.e: This refers to the style of promotion in which one is pushed out of his position and is advanced automatically, like the way tokoroten is squeezed out.
This refers to the style of promotion in which one is pushed out of his position and is advanced automatically, like the way tokoroten is squeezed out.
This refers to the style of promotion in which one is pushed out of his position and is advanced automatically, like the way tokoroten is squeezed out.

sen.j: 特に大相撲では、「大関は最大で五人」という慣例があることから、大関が五人いる状態で新横綱・新大関が同時に誕生すると「誰か昇進させないと六大関になってしまうから、（成績は満点とはいえないが）押し出されて横綱になった」という揶揄の意味で「ところてん式に昇進」といわれることがある。
sen.e: This applies especially to the case of grand sumo tournament where there is a custom that "there should not be more than five ozeki (sumo wrestler of the second highest rank)"; if new yokozuna (sumo grand champion) and new ozeki come into being simultaneously when there are already five ozeki, this is sometimes called "tokoroten-shiki promotion" with the suggestion that the new yokozuna "became yokozuna by being pushed out of ozeki's position (in spite of insufficient scores) since someone had to move upward in order to avoid there being six ozeki".

This applies especially to the case of grand sumo tournament where there is a custom that "there should not be more than five ozeki (sumo wrestler of the second highest rank)"; if new yokozuna (sumo grand champion) and new ozeki come into being simultaneously when there are already five ozeki, this situation is sometimes called "tokoroten-shiki promotion" implicating ironically that "the new yokozuna has become yokozuna by being pushed out of ozeki's position (in spite of insufficient scores) because someone had to move upward in order to avoid having six ozeki."

This applies especially to the case of grand sumo tournament where there is a custom that "there should not be more than five ozeki (sumo wrestler of the second highest rank)"; if new yokozuna (sumo grand champion) and new ozeki come into being simultaneously when there are already five ozeki, this situation is sometimes called "tokoroten-shiki promotion" implicating ironically that "the new yokozuna has become yokozuna by being pushed out of ozeki's position (in spite of insufficient scores) because someone had to move upward in order to avoid having six ozeki."
